articles.headline: France and U.S. Move Toward Temporary Truce in Trade War
articles.snippet: The détente emerged after Presidents Macron and Trump agreed to grant more time for talks over a global solution to taxing Amazon, Facebook and other digital giants.
articles.abstract: The détente emerged after Presidents Macron and Trump agreed to grant more time for talks over a global solution to taxing Amazon, Facebook and other digital giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — France and the United States appeared to strike a temporary truce in a trans-Atlantic spat, French officials said Tuesday, after President Emmanuel Macron agreed to suspend a tax on American technology giants in exchange for a postponement of threatened retaliatory tariffs on French goods by the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman, Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Architect of C.I.A. Interrogation Program Testifies at Guantánamo Bay
articles.snippet: Appearing for the first time at the military war court, James Mitchell was defiant, saying he was there for the benefit of the victims of the 9/11 attacks and their families.
articles.abstract: Appearing for the first time at the military war court, James Mitchell was defiant, saying he was there for the benefit of the victims of the 9/11 attacks and their families.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

articles.headline: This Company Says It Will Fix Your Smile. It May Shush You if It Doesn’t.
articles.snippet: SmileDirectClub, which sells teeth aligners online, has worked to limit information about customer dissatisfaction.
articles.abstract: SmileDirectClub, which sells teeth aligners online, has worked to limit information about customer dissatisfaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: To fix some crowding in her teeth, Taylor Weakley, an environmental scientist in Denver, ordered teeth aligners two years ago from SmileDirectClub, a start-up she had seen advertised on social media.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Boeing Pushes Back 737 Max Return Again
articles.snippet: The company told airlines it did not expect regulators to approve the plane to fly until June or July, the latest in a string of setbacks.
articles.abstract: The company told airlines it did not expect regulators to approve the plane to fly until June or July, the latest in a string of setbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The return of Boeing’s 737 Max has been delayed again. On Tuesday, the company said it did not expect regulators to approve the jet to fly again until the middle of the year. American Airlines, United and Southwest had already taken Max flights off their schedules until June, and if this new timeline holds, it would further push back when the plane will be available for commercial flights.

articles.headline: Republicans Block Subpoenas for New Evidence as Impeachment Trial Begins
articles.snippet: Republicans made last-minute changes to their proposed rules to placate moderates, but they held together to turn back Democratic efforts to subpoena documents.
articles.abstract: Republicans made last-minute changes to their proposed rules to placate moderates, but they held together to turn back Democratic efforts to subpoena documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided Senate began the impeachment trial of President Trump on Tuesday in utter acrimony, as Republicans blocked Democrats’ efforts to subpoena witnesses and documents related to Ukraine and moderate Republicans forced last-minute changes to rules that had been tailored to the president’s wishes.

articles.headline: Wuhan, Center of Coronavirus Outbreak, Is Being Cut Off by Chinese Authorities
articles.snippet: The sudden restrictions — announced after the official death toll nearly doubled — could upend the travel plans of millions of Chinese citizens, who travel in huge numbers during the Lunar New Year holiday.
articles.abstract: The sudden restrictions — announced after the official death toll nearly doubled — could upend the travel plans of millions of Chinese citizens, who travel in huge numbers during the Lunar New Year holiday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese authorities on Thursday morning closed off Wuhan — a city of more than 11 million people and the epicenter of a pneumonia-like virus that has spread halfway around the world — by canceling planes and trains leaving the city, and suspending buses, subways and ferries within it.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin and Vivian Wang

articles.headline: The Trade War, Paused for Now, Is Still Wreaking Damage
articles.snippet: Manufacturers and farmers struggled last year because of tariffs, and there are signs that damage is spreading to other sectors of the economy.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers and farmers struggled last year because of tariffs, and there are signs that damage is spreading to other sectors of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trade war is de-escalating, at least for now. But the economic damage it caused could be far from over.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Niraj Chokshi and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Chaos as Militants Overran Airfield, Killing 3 Americans in Kenya
articles.snippet: The brazen Shabab assault at Manda Bay, Kenya, a sleepy seaside base near the Somali border, on Jan. 5 left three Americans dead, raising complex questions about the military’s mission in Africa.
articles.abstract: The brazen Shabab assault at Manda Bay, Kenya, a sleepy seaside base near the Somali border, on Jan. 5 left three Americans dead, raising complex questions about the military’s mission in Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Armed with rifles and explosives, about a dozen Shabab fighters destroyed an American surveillance plane as it was taking off and ignited an hourslong gunfight earlier this month on a sprawling military base in Kenya that houses United States troops. By the time the Shabab were done, portions of the airfield were burning and three Americans were dead.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Helene Cooper
